Message.Title: some dude in Barrons like INTC
Message.Msg: He also liked CSCO and WDC which I own. INTC just makes my criteria as a value tech. Big techs with leading-edge proprietary technology I consider a deep value at an enterprise value to gross margin ratio of under about 3. And at a enterprise value to earnings ratio of under 10. INTC just barely makes the cut on both of those. I'll be buying some tomorrow.

Topic.Title: Stacy Smith for CEO?

Message.Msg: Brian Krzanich is a solid manufacturing and operations guy...but I think Intel needs a more charismatic, driven tech visionary. Intel has been an engineering and manufacturing for most of its existence...but the new business reality is - you have to understand where the market is going and lead it. You can't just sell what you make....which Intel used to do in the Craig Barrett days. Otellini was a good marketing/business guy, but he had to fight from behind due to AMD Opteron, x86-64. And then the mobile world with low-power processors moved too fast for him to catch up. I think Otellini did a good job turning a giant ship, but have been frustrated that it wasn't fast enough. Coming back, you need a fairly, charismatic tech visionary to put Intel back in the driver's seat. Not sure Stacy Smith can deliver this. Mike Bell will some day fit the bill. However, in the near-term, Intel may have to go out and hire someone.

Topic.Title: Stacy Smith for CEO?

Message.Msg: Brian Krzanich is a solid manufacturing and operations guy...but I think Intel needs a more charismatic, driven tech visionary. Intel has been an engineering and manufacturing for most of its existence...but the new business reality is - you have to understand where the market is going and lead it. You can't just sell what you make....which Intel used to do in the Craig Barrett days. Otellini was a good marketing/business guy, but he had to fight from behind due to AMD Opteron, x86-64. And then the mobile world with low-power processors moved too fast for him to catch up. I think Otellini did a good job turning a giant ship, but have been frustrated that it wasn't fast enough. Coming back, you need a fairly, charismatic tech visionary to put Intel back in the driver's seat. Not sure Stacy Smith can deliver this. Mike Bell will some day fit the bill. However, in the near-term, Intel may have to go out and hire someone. My vote is for Pat Gelsinger, if Intel can get him back. Good charisma, good visionary (Radio Free Intel), and came across to everyone as pretty dynamic. And he may be fairly well accepted by the current executive cadre as well.

Topic.Title: Stacy Smith for CEO?

Message.Msg: I agree Pat Gelsinger is the best choice....he has good understanding of Cloud computing (and effects of mobile devices) which is where everything is going and Intel will play a major role in it.

Topic.Title: I got a call from SEC regarding my naked short "whistle"

Message.Msg: Please explain. I sell you my shares on a regular short, I borrowed them from someone else. Since you have the real shares, the company pays you the real dividend, and I have to pay "payment in lieu of dividends" to the person I borrowed them from. Now if my short was naked, there are no real stocks, so the company is not paying you the dividend. You certainly expect to get the dividend, right? So don't I have to pay you the dividend? In fact, if I am paying it rather than the company, you will not get a dividend, but "payment in lieu of dividend"; your broker should be asking how that happened since they never lent the shares out... or you can complain because you can't get the favorable dividend rate on that... you'd ask your broker, who would open an investigation, etc. So to begin with, I don't see how i can naked short the shares and not have to pay the buyer the dividend, and even if I do, the fact that the payment is not a dividend should be a huge red flag.

Topic.Title: I got a call from SEC regarding my naked short "whistle"

Message.Msg: "Please explain. I sell you my ..." Paragraph #1. You are correct. "Now if my short was naked, there are no real stocks .... " The shareholder of record will be the buyer of your shorted shares. They expect to get payment from the company. The shorter pays the "in lieu" to the person they borrowed shares from. Since real shares were not borrowed and delivered, the person who bought the naked shorted shares will not become a shareholder of record until the naked short is corrected. If they complain, the naked shorter probably pays. Many people will expect the dividend payment system to work and will not detect the missed dividend payment. This is not a retail investor making this $250,000,000 one day trade. The trader allocated a big chunk of $1bil to this single 3-day trade. They probably own unmonitored (SEC policed) access to one of the exhanges. What I did was to report a 10mil naked short across a dividend payment that seems, on the surface, to be an illegal transaction. For me, it is a free lotto ticket with what appears to be a possible multimillion dollar payday. Note that between the purchase day, Oct 27th and the close out date Nov 3rd, there wsa only one Intel specific downgrade. BMO Capital "An analyst at BMO Capital, Ambrish Srivastav, downgraded Intel (Nasdaq: INTC) to Market Perform Wednesday morning, while at the same time upgrading ARM Holdings (Nasdaq: ARMH) to Outperform."

Message.Title: Interesting statements from Intel's Mooly Eden
Message.Msg: Intel's Israel chief hints at more hardware moves - and one CEO candidate Summary: Intel SVP Mooly Eden gave some broad hints on the company's future direction at a talk in Tel Aviv, with hardware and succession planning on the agenda. By David Shamah for Tel Aviv Tech | December 3, 2012 -- 12:05 GMT (04:05 PST) We're used to seeing the term 'Intel Inside' on a host of products – but could the Intel nameplate become a common sight on the outside of a product? In light of comments by Mooly Eden, Intel SVP and president of Intel Israel, it seems to be a prospect that's within the realm of possibility. "Today it is about more than the processor," Eden told an event in Tel Aviv last week. "It's more about a system and a usage model." Mooly Eden (Credit: Intel) Eden made the comments during a question and answer session that covered a wide range of topics, including Intel's activities in Israel, new products and technologies, and – the elephant in the Intel room these days – who will lead the company after the departure of Paul Otellini next year. Unsurprisingly, Eden didn't reveal who the leading candidate to take the top job might be, and dispelled rumours of specific names flying around online. "It's the job of the board of directors to make this decision and I am sure they will make the right one. They are already discussing the choices." Candidates from inside and outside the company are being considered, and of course Intel insiders are the most likely to be chosen. "Dadi [Intel SVP David Perlmutter]," who is Israeli, "is definitely a candidate," said Eden, to the cheers of the hometown crowd. But it was Eden's response to questions about Intel's plans in the mobile space that gave a more concrete hint to where the company's future may lie. "What are you planning to do about this?" asked an audience member, holding up an iPhone. "I've got the answer right here," Eden responded without missing a beat, as he whipped out a Motorola RAZRi device - among the first, but by no means last, smartphone to use Intel chips. So far, there are half a dozen Intel Inside smartphones, available in Europe and India - but expect to see a lot more in the coming months. "We are at least a year ahead of everyone else in the mobile space in processors and chips," said Eden. "If we can't grab a significant share of the market, it will be our own fault." 'Usage model' But Intel may be planning to go even further. "Today it's more about an overall system, a usage model," Eden said. "The tech culture in Israel has grown to be able to provide solutions for systems." Eden did not elaborate on what he meant by a "usage model," but the term has been bandied about by a number of companies, and could well refer to the hardware/software/cloud/marketing strategy popularised by Apple, in which users are locked into an 'ecosystem' controlled by the company. Read this A junior Silicon Valley: Microsoft Israel on start-ups, security and Steve Ballmer Read more If it's a model Intel is considering, it would be following in the footsteps of Microsoft. Traditionally primarily a software company, Microsoft has recently ramped up its hardware business, alongside its ongoing cloud and app store efforts. Microsoft has come to terms with the need to go for the "usage model", and is working on expanding its offerings. On his recent visit to Israel, Microsoft chief Steve Ballmer said that "until now Microsoft has been about software, but now we have to look at devices. A lot of innovative technology is going to be delivered in devices, and a lot of that technology, regardless of the front end, is going to be a cloud service." This is the future of tech, said Ballmer, "and we aim to be in the forefront of this transition". If Intel has made a similar commitment, Eden did not specifically mention it. But it appears that Intel is planning to go beyond its current offerings, embracing new opportunities. The proof? In a side conversation, Eden mentioned that the company is planning a new device (I was asked not to reveal what kind of device, but it's definitely innovative and is far outside the company's usual suite of offerings) to which it is putting the finishing touches (the SDK is apparently already available to select developers). It's a consumer-oriented device, being developed at Intel Israel R&D centre in Haifa, and will be unveiled at the CES trade show early next year. And the device will be a new one for Intel, so it may not be subject to deals the company has with manufacturers that already sell Intel-powered laptops and ultrabooks. Will this be the firm's first opportunity to introduce an 'Intel Outside' product?

Topic.Title: And if Apple or Intel announce they won't be working together?

Message.Msg: If Apple was dumb and arrogant enough to do this then it will be their own folly. "Apple has a history of getting way too cocky for their own good--giving the entire industry the finger and making everything proprietary once they taste success. Without the switch to x86, we wouldn't even be having this conversation about Apple; it was the best decision the company ever made. If they switch all their products to a secret, blackbox custom ARM-derivative architecture, it's back to the PPC days of limited software, slower speeds and zero multiboot options. ARM may be good for power consumption on small devices, but x86 is mandatory for a real computery computer." "And to be honest, what the hell is wrong with some of you people? Why would you want Intel out of the Mac? Intel makes the best consumer CPU's in the world, hands down. There is ZERO competition, isn't Apple all about providing the best user experience? Intel CPU's give the Mac desktop and Laptops tons of performance, great battery life, and compatibility with multiplate OS's, if Apple replaced intel CPU's with some ****** in house ARM chip. I could see Mac sales crashing, very quickly. "

Topic.Title: I got a call from SEC regarding my naked short "whistle"

Message.Msg: First, a missing INTC payment would certainly be missed. Second, i think the brokerage firms would notice the missing payment and would follow up. After all, they need to allocate the dividends to all their holders, as they are the holder of record of most stocks in their firm ("street name")... and they need to know whether to report "in iieu" payments. Their true dividends come from the company itself; I can't even imagine how they get other payments... other than true "in lieu" payments when THEY lent the shares. So prob'ly, if they think they have true shares, they will notice a shortage as they allocate them to the beneficial holders... maybe they contact the company, etc., at which time I would think the whole scheme would get exposed. I think having a naked short position is MOST vulnerable to exposure across a dividend for just this reason.

Message.Title: Motorola RAZR I finally is on Geekbench
Message.Msg: Search for Z2480 to get the full details at browserDOTprimatelabsDOTcom Geekbench Score: 1029 Integer Processor integer performance 1029 Floating Point Processor floating point performance 1201 Memory Memory performance 1110 Stream Memory bandwidth performance 1004 As you can see from the android benchmarks list below (browserDOTprimatelabsDOTcom/android-benchmarks) the results aren't great. At first I thought it may be because it's running emulated ARM code (which I guess, is still possible) but the tests do say "Geekbench 2.3.4 for Android x86" and the single threaded results are in line with the Clovertrail (Z2760) on Windows 8 (which are around the 1400 mark). Topic.Title: Motorola RAZR I finally is on Geekbench

Message.Msg: Geekbench is a reputable benchmark. They're not some no-name benchmark off the street that would publish dubious numbers about such a reputed brand glibly. These numbers are consistent with the original numbers that came out for Medfield when Anandtech compared it with some of the other phones at the time and it came out middle of the pack. It seems to me, someone has influenced the benchmark creators into creating benchmarks that are heavy on Javascript and these have been favoring the Intel chips. That's why all these Intel obsessed technical commentators have started tooting Intel's horn on how they've suddenly caught up on power/performance. Otherwise, there's no change in the chip from the origional Medfield to the Razr i 2GHz version except for the clock and that is obviously at the expense of battery life. The Razr i for the record has a 40% bigger battery than the iPhone 5.

Topic.Title: I got a call from SEC regarding my naked short "whistle"

Message.Msg: I have scatched my head on all the issues that you have raised trying to figure out what the large transactions represent. The information is not easily located. Most public information that I have found deals with the broker-client relationship. If you seartch for DTCC DSS, you will find the DTCC Dividend Settlement Service which is set up to settle dividend and interest claims among members. I haven't found any statistics or information on fails to delliver actions. I just decided to point out the 10m share spike in Intel fails to deliver over the ex-dividend day and see if there was any problem.

Message.Title: Is Intel about to become Apple’s ARM SoC foundry?
Message.Msg: If an industry analyst is to be believed, Apple may soon move the production of its ARM processors from Samsung to Intel. This dovetails neatly with the news earlier in the year that Intel was moving into the foundry business — but it isn’t quite that simple: The same analyst says that, as part of the deal, Apple will have to transition its iPads away from ARM to an Intel x86 SoC. This information comes from Doug Freedman, an analyst at RBC Capital. The exact details are as follows: Intel would take on the production of the ARM SoCs found in the iPhone (and presumably the iPod); in exchange, Apple would switch to an x86 SoC in the iPad. From Extreme Tech

Message.Title: Apple may soon move the production of its ARM processors from Samsung to Intel.
Message.Msg: If an industry analyst is to be believed, Apple may soon move the production of its ARM processors from Samsung to Intel. This dovetails neatly with the news earlier in the year that Intel was moving into the foundry business — but it isn’t quite that simple: The same analyst says that, as part of the deal, Apple will have to transition its iPads away from ARM to an Intel x86 SoC.

Message.Title: At $399, even Europe could afford one
Message.Msg: Acer has unveiled a rather interesting 11.6-inch notebook designed specifically with cash strapped students in mind. The TravelMate B113 features a 1366x768 screen, Core i3 Ivy Bridge processor, 4GB of RAM and a 500GB hard drive with Windows 8 on top. Not bad for a $399 device weighing in at just 3lbs. The B113 is shipping in the US and Canada, but there’s no word on availability in Europe and the rest of the world just yet.

Message.Title: Quad-core microprocessor notebook shipments set to nearly quadruple in 2016
Message.Msg: Notebooks during the next four years increasingly will adopt quad-core microprocessors, with all types of models bulking up their computing power amid the rising competitive challenge posed by media tablets and smartphones. Shipments of notebooks configured with quad-core microprocessors will nearly quadruple from 2012 to 2016, according to an IHS iSuppli. Quad-core-equipped notebook shipments will reach 179 million units by 2016, making up 59% of all notebooks that year. That compares to 48 million units in 2012, representing 22% of all notebooks shipped in 2012.

Topic.Title: Quad-core microprocessor notebook shipments set to nearly quadruple in 2016

Message.Title: Intel to put Ivy Bridge on diet
Message.Msg: Aims to slash power consumption Intel is apparently working hard to reduce power consumption on some of its Ivy Bridge processors. According to CNET, future versions of the chip will feature a significant drop in power consumption, ending up with well north of 17 watts. There is a chance the new chips will be efficient enough to use in tablets, and let’s not forget that Microsoft is already using an Ivy chip in the Surface Pro. Intel is apparently trying to fill the gap between power efficient Z-series Atoms, which trade performance for efficiency, and proper Ivy-based processors with plenty of oomph for discerning consumers. Of course, the new chips have applications far beyond tablets, as they could end up in ultrabooks and other ultraportable devices. If Windows 8 tablets take off next year, power efficient Ivy Bridge parts could be in high demand.

Message.Title: This guy doubts Apple and Intel, but says Bay Trail will probably be a show stopper for the market
Message.Msg: Is Intel about to become Apple’s ARM SoC foundry? By Sebastian Anthony on December 3, 2012 at 1:32 pm For me, though, the biggest giveaway that Freedman’s sources are incorrect is that tidbit about Intel forcing Apple to move its iPad to x86. It certainly makes sense from Intel’s perspective, which is desperately trying to break into the mobile market — now with Clover Trail, which is fairly exciting, and next year with Bay Trail, which will probably blow the doors off everything else on the market. I’m not sure if I can picture Apple splitting its iOS platform into two different architectures, though, just to get into bed with Intel. Maybe that’s the only option, though, if Apple really wants to drop Samsung and TSMC doesn’t have the capacity.
